tools.name: CreateFile
tools.description:
Create a new file or overwrite an existing file in a repository.

The explicit mode parameter reduces accidental data loss: the default CREATE mode refuses to
touch existing files, while OVERWRITE must be chosen intentionally.

parameters.description: The account owner of the repository.

parameters.name: repo
parameters.description: The name of the repository without the .git extension.

parameters.name: path
parameters.description: The content path.

parameters.name: content
parameters.description: The content of the file.

parameters.name: message
parameters.description: The commit message.

parameters.name: branch
parameters.description: The branch name.

parameters.name: mode
parameters.description: How to handle existing files. Default is FileMode.CREATE

content.value: This is an example content for the file.

tools.name: CreateReplyForReviewComment
tools.description:
Create a reply to a review comment for a pull request.

Optionally resolve the conversation thread after replying by setting resolve_thread=True
and providing the thread_id (GraphQL Node ID).

parameters.name: owner

parameters.name: repo

parameters.name: pull_number
parameters.description: The number that identifies the pull request.

parameters.name: comment_id
parameters.description: The unique identifier of the comment.

parameters.name: body
parameters.description: The text of the review comment.

parameters.name: thread_id
parameters.description: Optional GraphQL Node ID of the review thread to resolve after replying.

parameters.name: resolve_thread
parameters.description: Whether to resolve the thread after replying. Default is False.

body.value: Thanks for your feedback! I've made the suggested changes.

codeExample.tabLabel: Call the Tool with User Authorization

tools.name: CreateReviewComment
tools.description:
Create a review comment for a pull request in a GitHub repository.

IMPORTANT: Line numbers must be part of the diff (changed lines only).
GitHub's API requires line numbers that exist in the pull request diff, not just any line
in the file. If the line wasn't changed in the PR, the comment will fail with 422 error.

If the subject_type is not 'file', then the start_line and end_line parameters are required.
If the subject_type is 'file', then the start_line and end_line parameters are ignored.
If the commit_id is not provided, the latest commit SHA from the PR will be used.

TIP: Use subject_type='file' to comment on the entire file if unsure about line positions.

parameters.name: owner
parameters.description: The account owner of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: repo
parameters.description: The name of the repository without the .git extension. The name is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: pull_number
parameters.description: The number that identifies the pull request.

parameters.name: body
parameters.description: The text of the review comment.

parameters.name: path
parameters.description: The relative path to the file that necessitates a comment.

parameters.name: commit_id
parameters.description: The SHA of the commit needing a comment. If not provided, the latest commit SHA from the PR will be used.

parameters.name: start_line
parameters.description: The start line of the range of lines in the pull request diff that the comment applies to. Required unless 'subject_type' is 'file'.

parameters.name: end_line
parameters.description: The end line of the range of lines in the pull request diff that the comment applies to. Required unless 'subject_type' is 'file'.

parameters.name: side
parameters.description: The side of the diff that the pull request's changes appear on. Use LEFT for deletions that appear in red. Use RIGHT for additions that appear in green or unchanged lines that appear in white and are shown for context. Default is RIGHT.

parameters.name: start_side
parameters.description: The starting side of the diff that the comment applies to.

parameters.name: subject_type
parameters.description: The type of subject that the comment applies to. Default is file.

body.value: This change looks good, but please revise the variable naming for clarity.

codeExample.tabLabel: Call the Tool with User Authorization

tools.name: GetFileContents
tools.description:
Get the contents of a file in a repository.

Returns the decoded content (if text) along with metadata like SHA, size, and line count.
For large files, use start_line and end_line to retrieve specific line ranges.

parameters.name: owner
parameters.description: The account owner of the repository.

parameters.name: repo
parameters.description: The name of the repository without the .git extension.

parameters.name: path
parameters.description: Path within the repository relative to its root; omit owner/repo prefixes.

parameters.name: ref
parameters.description: The name of the commit/branch/tag. Default: the repository's default branch.

parameters.name: start_line
parameters.description: First line to retrieve (1-indexed). Default: None (entire file).

parameters.name: end_line
parameters.description: Last line to retrieve (1-indexed, inclusive). Default: None (entire file).

tools.name: ListRepositoryActivities
tools.description:
List repository activities.

Retrieves a detailed history of changes to a repository, such as pushes, merges,
force pushes, and branch changes, and associates these changes with commits and users.

parameters.name: owner
parameters.description: The account owner of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: repo
parameters.description: The name of the repository without the .git extension. The name is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: direction
parameters.description: The direction to sort the results by. Default is desc.

parameters.name: per_page
parameters.description: The number of results per page (max 100). Default is 30.

parameters.name: before
parameters.description: A cursor (unique ID, e.g., a SHA of a commit) to search for results before this cursor.

parameters.name: after
parameters.description: A cursor (unique ID, e.g., a SHA of a commit) to search for results after this cursor.

parameters.name: ref
parameters.description: The Git reference for the activities you want to list. The ref for a branch can be formatted either as refs/heads/BRANCH_NAME or BRANCH_NAME, where BRANCH_NAME is the name of your branch.

parameters.name: actor
parameters.description: The GitHub username to filter by the actor who performed the activity.

parameters.name: time_period
parameters.description: The time period to filter by.

parameters.name: activity_type
parameters.description: The activity type to filter by.

codeExample.tabLabel: Call the Tool with User Authorization

tools.name: ListRepositoryCollaborators
tools.description:
List collaborators for a repository.

Returns users who have access to the repository and can be requested as reviewers
for pull requests. Useful for discovering who can review your PR.

Detail levels:
- basic: Only explicit collaborators (fast, minimal API calls)
- include_org_members: Add all org members (default, moderate API calls)
- full_profiles: Add org members + enrich with names/emails (slow, many API calls)

parameters.name: owner
parameters.description: The account owner of the repository.

parameters.name: repo
parameters.description: The name of the repository without the .git extension.

parameters.name: affiliation
parameters.description: Filter by affiliation type. Default is all.

parameters.name: permission
parameters.description: Filter by permission level. Default returns all permission levels.

parameters.name: detail_level
parameters.description: Detail level to include when listing collaborators. Default is include_org_members.

parameters.name: include_teams
parameters.description: Include teams that have access to the repository. Teams can be requested as reviewers using their slug. Default is True.

parameters.name: per_page
parameters.description: Number of collaborators per page (max 100). Default is 30.

parameters.name: page
parameters.description: Page number of results to fetch. Default is 1.

output.description: List of repository collaborators and teams who can review PRs

tools.name: SearchMyRepos
tools.description: Search repositories accessible to the authenticated user with fuzzy matching.

parameters.name: repo_name
parameters.description: Repository name or partial name to search for

parameters.name: scope
parameters.description: Where to search. Default is all.

parameters.name: organization
parameters.description: Organization name when scope is 'organization'. If omitted, searches all of your organizations.

parameters.name: auto_accept_matches
parameters.description: Auto-accept fuzzy matches above 0.9 confidence. Default is False

parameters.name: include_recent_branches
parameters.description: Include up to this many recent branches per repository (0 disables, default 10, max 30).

codeExample.tabLabel: Call the Tool with User Authorization

tools.name: SearchProjectItem
tools.description: Search for a specific item in a Projects V2 project.

parameters.name: project_search_mode
parameters.description: Select project lookup by number or name

parameters.name: project_identifier
parameters.description: Project number or title

parameters.name: item_search_mode
parameters.description: Select item lookup by ID or title

parameters.name: item_identifier
parameters.description: Item ID or title

parameters.name: scope_target
parameters.description: Where the project lives

parameters.name: scope_identifier
parameters.description: Owner reference

parameters.name: auto_accept_matches
parameters.description: Auto-accept fuzzy matches above 0.9 confidence. Default is False

codeExample.tabLabel: Call the Tool with User Authorization

tools.name: SetStarred
tools.description: Star or un-star a GitHub repository.

parameters.name: owner
parameters.description: The owner of the repository

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: The name of the repository

parameters.name: starred
parameters.description: Whether to star the repository or not. Default is True.

codeExample.tabLabel: Call the Tool with User Authorization

tools.name: SubmitPullRequestReview
tools.description: Submit a review for a pull request.

parameters.name: owner
parameters.description: The account owner of the repository.

parameters.name: repo
parameters.description: The name of the repository without the .git extension.

parameters.name: pull_request_number
parameters.description: The number that identifies the pull request.

parameters.name: event
parameters.description: The review action to perform.

parameters.name: body
parameters.description: The body text of the review. Required when event is REQUEST_CHANGES or COMMENT.

codeExample.tabLabel: Call the Tool with User Authorization

tools.name: UpdateFileLines
tools.description:
Replace a block of lines within a file (1-indexed, inclusive). Set mode=FileUpdateMode.APPEND
to add new content to the end of the file.

parameters.name: owner
parameters.description: The account owner of the repository.

parameters.name: repo
parameters.description: The name of the repository without the .git extension.

parameters.name: path
parameters.description: The content path.

parameters.name: branch
parameters.description: The branch to update.

parameters.name: new_content
parameters.description: The replacement lines (no need to include trailing newline).

parameters.name: message
parameters.description: The commit message describing the change.

parameters.name: start_line
parameters.description: First line to replace (1-indexed). Required when mode is FileUpdateMode.REPLACE; ignored when mode is FileUpdateMode.APPEND.

parameters.name: end_line
parameters.description: Last line to replace (1-indexed, inclusive). Required when mode is FileUpdateMode.REPLACE; ignored when mode is FileUpdateMode.APPEND.

parameters.name: mode
parameters.description: How to apply the change. Default is FileUpdateMode.REPLACE

new_content.value: This is the new content to append.

message.value: Update file to append new content.

codeExample.tabLabel: Call the Tool with User Authorization

tools.name: UpdateIssue
tools.description:
Update an issue in a GitHub repository.

Parameters that are not provided (None) will not be updated or cleared.
Updates apply to the issue in the repository. If the issue is in a project,
the project item will automatically reflect these changes.

parameters.name: owner
parameters.description: The account owner of the repository

parameters.name: repo
parameters.description: The name of the repository

parameters.name: issue_number
parameters.description: The number that identifies the issue

parameters.name: title
parameters.description: The new title. Not provided = unchanged.

parameters.name: body
parameters.description: The new contents. Not provided = unchanged.

parameters.name: state
parameters.description: State of the issue. Not provided = unchanged.

parameters.name: labels
parameters.description: Labels to set (replaces existing). Not provided = unchanged.

parameters.name: assignees
parameters.description: Assignees to set (replaces existing). Not provided = unchanged.

parameters.name: milestone
parameters.description: Milestone number. Not provided = unchanged.

body.value: This is the updated description of the issue.

codeExample.tabLabel: Call the Tool with User Authorization

tools.name: UpdatePullRequest
tools.description: Update a pull request in a GitHub repository.

parameters.name: owner
parameters.description: The account owner of the repository. The name is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: repo
parameters.description: The name of the repository without the .git extension. The name is not case sensitive.

parameters.name: pull_number
parameters.description: The number that identifies the pull request.

parameters.name: title
parameters.description: The title of the pull request.

parameters.name: body
parameters.description: The contents of the pull request.

parameters.name: append_body
parameters.description: If True, append to existing body instead of replacing it. Default is False.

parameters.name: state
parameters.description: State of this Pull Request.

parameters.name: base
parameters.description: The name of the branch you want your changes pulled into.

body.value: This pull request addresses the implementation of Feature X.

codeExample.tabLabel: Call the Tool with User Authorization

tools.name: WhoAmI
tools.description:
Get information about the authenticated GitHub user.

Returns profile, organizations, and teams.

output.description: User profile with organizations and teams

codeExample.tabLabel: Call the Tool with User Authorization

documentationChunks.content:
**Critical**: This MCP Server is built for **GitHub Apps**, not OAuth Apps.
  
  You **must** create a GitHub App (not an OAuth App) to use this server properly. 
  
   [Complete GitHub App Setup Guide](/references/auth-providers/github)
**Configuration Required**: All tools require secrets to be configured in Arcade Dashboard. See [Secrets Setup](#secrets-setup) below.

## GitHub Enterprise Support

<Callout type="info">
  This MCP Server fully supports **GitHub Enterprise Server 2.22+**
</Callout>

**Default Configuration:**
- If no `GITHUB_SERVER_URL` is configured, the default is `https://api.github.com` (GitHub.com)
- All tools work with GitHub.com out of the box

**For GitHub Enterprise Server:**

1. Create your GitHub App on your Enterprise instance (not github.com)
2. Configure the `GITHUB_SERVER_URL` secret in Arcade Dashboard (see [Secrets Setup](#secrets-setup) below)
3. Use your Enterprise server's API endpoint

**Example Enterprise Server URLs:**
- `https://github.yourcompany.com/api/v3`
- `https://enterprise.yourorg.com/api/v3`
- `https://git.company.internal/api/v3`

<Callout>
  **Note**: GitHub Enterprise Server uses the `/api/v3` path after the hostname. GitHub.com uses `https://api.github.com` (no `/api/v3` suffix).
</Callout>

---

## Configuration & Setup

### Authentication

<Callout type="warning">
  **Critical**: This MCP Server uses **GitHub Apps** authentication, not OAuth Apps.
  
  You **must** create a GitHub App to use this server. OAuth Apps are not supported.
</Callout>

The Arcade GitHub MCP Server uses the [GitHub auth provider](/references/auth-providers/github) to connect to users' GitHub accounts.

**For Arcade Cloud:**
- No configuration needed
- Your users will see `Arcade` as the requesting application
- All tools work out of the box

**For Self-Hosted:**
- You must [create your own GitHub App](/references/auth-providers/github#creating-a-github-app)
- [Configure the GitHub auth provider](/references/auth-providers/github#configuring-github-auth-in-arcade) with your app credentials
- Your users will see your application name

<Callout type="info">
  **New to GitHub Apps?** Read [Why Arcade Uses GitHub Apps](/references/auth-providers/github#why-arcade-uses-github-apps-not-oauth-apps) 
  to understand the security and compliance benefits.
</Callout>

### Secrets Setup

All tools require secrets to be configured in Arcade Dashboard.

**Steps:**

1. Go to [Arcade Dashboard](https://api.arcade.dev/dashboard)
2. Navigate to **Secrets** in the left sidebar
3. Click **Add Secret**
4. Add the following secrets:

- **Secret Name**: `GITHUB_SERVER_URL`; **Value**: `https://api.github.com` (default for GitHub.com); **Required For**: All tools
- **Secret Name**: `GITHUB_CLASSIC_PERSONAL_ACCESS_TOKEN`; **Value**: Classic PAT with `notifications` scope; **Required For**: Notifications tools only


<Callout type="info">
  **Default**: If `GITHUB_SERVER_URL` is not configured, it defaults to `https://api.github.com` (GitHub.com)
  
  **GitHub Enterprise Users**: Set `GITHUB_SERVER_URL` to your Enterprise server's API endpoint (e.g., `https://github.yourcompany.com/api/v3`). Note that Enterprise uses `/api/v3` path. See [GitHub Enterprise Support](#github-enterprise-support) for details.
</Callout>

<Callout type="warning">
  **For Notifications Tools**: Create a classic Personal Access Token at [github.com/settings/tokens](https://github.com/settings/tokens) with only the `notifications` scope checked. GitHub Apps cannot access the notifications API.
</Callout>

---

## GitHub App Permissions Summary

When creating your GitHub App, grant the specific permissions below. This is a quick reference of which permissions are commonly required for repository, organization, and user-level actions.

<Callout type="info">
**Note:** `Metadata` read permission is automatically granted to GitHub Apps.
</Callout>

### Repository Permissions

- **Contents**  Read: All repository and pull request tools, getting file contents
- **Contents**  Write: Creating/updating files, creating branches, merging PRs
- **Issues**  Read & Write: Issue management, PR assignments, managing labels (issues)
- **Pull requests**  Read & Write: Pull request management, reviews, managing labels (pull requests)
- **Metadata**  Read: All tools (automatically granted)
- **Statuses**  Read: `CheckPullRequestMergeStatus`

### Organization Permissions

- **Members**  Read: Projects, collaborators, org repos, user search
- **Projects**  Read & Write: Projects V2 tools

### User Permissions

- **Read user profile**  Read: User-context tools, review workload
- **Act on behalf of user**  Enabled: `SetStarred` (starring repositories)

### Tools by Permission Requirements

**Basic Repository Access** (Contents Read + Metadata)
- `GetRepository`
- `CountStargazers`
- `ListStargazers`
- `ListRepositoryActivities`
- `GetFileContents`

**Repository Write** (Contents Write + Metadata)
- `CreateBranch`
- `CreateOrUpdateFile`
- `UpdateFileLines`

**Issue Management** (Contents Read + Issues + Metadata)
- `CreateIssue`
- `UpdateIssue`
- `GetIssue`
- `ListIssues`
- `CreateIssueComment`
- `ListRepositoryLabels`
- `ManageLabels` (for issues)

**Pull Request Read** (Contents + Pull requests Read + Metadata)
- `ListPullRequests`
- `GetPullRequest`
- `ListPullRequestCommits`
- `ListReviewCommentsOnPullRequest`
- `CheckPullRequestMergeStatus` (+ Statuses)

**Pull Request Write** (Contents Read + Pull requests Write + Metadata)
- `UpdatePullRequest`
- `CreatePullRequest`
- `SubmitPullRequestReview`
- `ManagePullRequest`
- `ManagePullRequestReviewers`
- `CreateReviewComment`
- `CreateReplyForReviewComment`
- `ResolveReviewThread`
- `ManageLabels` (for pull requests)
- `MergePullRequest` (+ Contents Write)

**Organization Tools** (Contents + Metadata + Members)
- `ListOrgRepositories`
- `SearchMyRepos`
- `ListRepositoryCollaborators`
- `AssignPullRequestUser` (+ Issues Write)

**Projects V2** (Contents + Metadata + Projects + Members)
- `ListProjects`
- `ListProjectItems`
- `SearchProjectItem`
- `ListProjectFields`
- `UpdateProjectItem` (Projects Write)

**User Context** (Contents + Metadata + Read user profile)
- `WhoAmI` (+ Members)
- `GetUserRecentActivity`
- `GetUserOpenItems`
- `GetReviewWorkload` (+ Pull requests Read)

** Special: Notifications** (Requires Classic PAT)
- `GetNotificationSummary`
- `ListNotifications`

<Callout type="warning">
**Warning:** GitHub Apps cannot access the Notifications API. Access to notifications requires a classic Personal Access Token with the `notifications` scope.
</Callout>

summary:
# Arcade Toolkit for GitHub

The Arcade Toolkit provides a suite of LLM tools designed to streamline interaction with GitHub, enabling developers to automate and enhance their workflows effectively.

## Capabilities
- Automate pull request and issue management, enabling seamless collaboration.
- Create, update, and delete files and branches within repositories.
- Retrieve detailed information about repositories, pull requests, and issues.
- Efficiently search and manage collaborators and labels across repositories.

## OAuth
- **Provider**: GitHub
- **Scopes**: None required.

## Secrets
- **Types**: webhook_secret, api_key, token.
- **Examples**: GITHUB_SERVER_URL, GITHUB_CLASSIC_PERSONAL_ACCESS_TOKEN.
